advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert of the Model 100.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTERS IN THE EXAM ROOM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> M5 PRO & M5 JR JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture!</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL GUIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO 7, the family computer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC.1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8086 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1982, Seattle Computer provided the 8086 version of the Gazelle with a free set of software: Microsoft MS-DOS, GW-Basic and the Perfect Writer word processor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is for the Micromachine 4000, but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPTEMBER 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #6 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Larry Greenfield and his <a href="http://www.tcp.com/%7Elgreenf/apfpage.htm" target="_blank">APF Imagination Machine page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.media: Two 5.25'' disk drives (360 KB each), 2S/DD disks, 40 tracks, 9 sectorsHard disk optional
computer.name: 16A
computer.ports: Power supply, keyboard, Centronics, RS232c, Video out, Video TV output, 8 expansion slots
